ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual leadership lab, asynchronous physical training

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A good understanding of leadership, team dynamics, and the making of an effective Air Force Officer. It seemed more relevant and worthwhile than other ROTC classes I've taken.
A broad overview of leadership and teamwork theories and styles.
I developed an understanding of the fundamentals of leadership from an academic perspective. I also learned about some of the most important traits of an Air Force officer.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The strength of this course is Col. Granholm. I really appreciated his insight into the material. I felt like we got a good picture of the Air Force and his role and experiences within it. With real world examples and case studies, the material just seemed more relevant and important than in previous AS classes. He treated us like capable adults, and it made a difference. In addition, the Col. Rodgers guest lecture was one of the most motivating and enjoyable lectures I've ever attended. 

The weakness of AS202 has to be the material. There's not much a course director can do about this, Holm Center dictates the requisite packets and material. With topics like "Kelly's two dimensional model of followership" and comparing the 3 methods of problem-solving, this simply isn't going to be the most intellectually engaging course you'll have at Yale. Nevertheless, Col. Granholm made it a good experience and I did truly enjoy the course.
This course was interesting and was taught really well. The work level was appropriate for the course and I enjoyed every discussion session.

The strength was definitely Col Graholm's decision to format the course in order to emphasize the ideas he found to be most important. He also brought in engaging and insightful guest speakers who complemented the content of the course well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Course did a good job adapting to the virtual format.
This course worked well over Zoom because it was a discussion format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're an AFROTC cadet.
